meanings.sent1: She felt vindicated when the truth came out and showed she was innocent.
meanings.sent2: The evidence presented in court vindicated her, proving she had done nothing wrong.
meanings.sent3: After the mix-up was resolved, she felt vindicated and relieved that her name was cleared.
meanings.sent4: The shining alibi vindicated her, washing away any doubts about her innocence.
meanings.sent5: The clear video footage was the vindicated proof she needed to show she was blameless.

meanings.sent1: His actions were vindicated by the law, proving he had acted within his rights.
meanings.sent2: The decision to intervene was vindicated when it prevented a major disaster.
meanings.sent3: The bold move to speak up was vindicated by the positive outcome it brought.
meanings.sent4: Her choice to confront the issue directly vindicated her courage and determination.
meanings.sent5: The supportive statements from witnesses vindicated his version of events, showing he was justified in his actions.

meanings.definition: Proven to be right or justified
meanings.sent1: His predictions were vindicated when the results matched exactly what he had foreseen.
meanings.sent2: The research findings vindicated her hypothesis, confirming it to be accurate.
meanings.sent3: The lucky guess she made was vindicated when it turned out to be the correct answer.
meanings.sent4: The successful outcome of the project vindicated their hard work and dedication.
meanings.sent5: The final verdict vindicated his long-held belief that honesty always prevails in the end.
